Line 177: Line 177:
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 killed' so far in Egypt protests: News24: Africa: News|publisher=News24|date=2010-12-18|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 killed' so far in Egypt protests: News24: Africa: News|publisher=News24|date=2010-12-18|accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
â
In the late evening President Mubarak proclaimed he will not run for another term in the next election.<ref>[http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn]</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office until the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make politicial reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities persue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation.".<ref>http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true</ref> Crowds continued protesting in Tahrir Square, demanding that the president step down.<ref>http://www.charter.net/video/play/429085/channels/cnn</ref><ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html</ref> There were reports that Mubarak's proclamation came after President Barack Obama's special envoy, [[Frank G. Wisner]], told Mubarak the U.S. saw his presidency at an end and urged him to prepare for an orderly transition to real democracy.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110201/D9L48QIO0.html Obama envoy told Mubarak tenure coming to a close]</ref>
+
In the late evening President Mubarak proclaimed he will not run for another term in the next election.<ref>[http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn]</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office until the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make politicial reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities persue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation.".<ref>http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true</ref> Crowds continued protesting in Tahrir Square, demanding that the president step down.<ref>http://www.charter.net/video/play/429085/channels/cnn</ref><ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html</ref> [[Contents of the United States diplomatic cables leak (Region â Middle East)|According to wikileaks]] Mubarak had planed to stay in power until he dies due to the absence of free and fair elections means he will almost certainly hold the post for as long as he is willing to stand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/dec/09/wikileaks-cables-hosni-mubarak-succession?DCMP=EMC-thewrap08|title=WikiLeaks Cables Cast Hosni Mubarak as Egypt's Ruler for Life — US Ambassador Tells Hillary Clinton that President Will Win Rigged Election Next Year, His 30th in Power|work=[[The Guardian]]|author=Tisdall, Simon |date=9 December 2010|accessdate=11 December 2010}}</ref><ref name="09CAIRO874">{{cite document| last =Scobey| first = Margaret| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Scenesetter: President Mubarak's visit to Washington| id={{WikiLeaks cable|09CAIRO874}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date =2009-05-19| url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/05/09CAIRO874.html |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-01-18 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vq2wl2xM |archivedate=2011-01-18 |deadurl=no }}</ref> There were reports that Mubarak's proclamation came after President Barack Obama's special envoy, [[Frank G. Wisner]], told Mubarak the U.S. saw his presidency at an end and urged him to prepare for an orderly transition to real democracy.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110201/D9L48QIO0.html Obama envoy told Mubarak tenure coming to a close]</ref>
